title: What time signature is Norwegian Wood in? I'm trying to play along to it. It seems to be in E myxolydian, and I have the melody roughly down but can't figure out the time. - Quora

response.answer_text: Unfortunately, I don't have a handy score of “Norwegian Wood” to refer to, but I have just been listening to my recording of it, and I would describe this song as being written in 6/8 time. This is similar to 3/4 time, but 3/4 time (a fast waltz time, at the speed that Norwegian Wood is played) would mean that there are three single beats (crotchets) in each bar. This song, in 6/8 time, has six quavers in each bar, divided into two groups of three, with a strong beat at the beginning of each group. A quaver is, lengthwise, half of a crotchet. It sounds a bit like it is in three time, but no; not quite. In the eighteenth century, 6/8 time was sometimes described as “Sicilienne” time, after the elegant dance which featured a dotted (slightly lengthened) note on each first note of each group of three quavers. You can hear a tendency towards this dotting in the guitar accompaniment to Norwegian Wood, especially between each phrase of the minor key part of the tune ( where he “noticed there wasn't a chair” and he “crawled off to sleep in the bath” ). So, six half-notes in each bar is your rhythmic cue. Emphasising the strong beats slightly, and the tendency towards dotting the strong beats, will give the song forward motion and lilt.

It’s in a slow 12/8. So you count 4 main beats, but each one is divided into 3. / Once __ __ / I met a / girl __ __ / Or should I // / Say __ __ / She once met / Me __ __ / __ __ __ // / She __ __ / showed me her / room __ __ / is-n’t it // / Good __ __ / Nor-we-gian / Wood __ __ / __ __ __ // You can think of it in a fast 3/4, it’s true - but the reality is more complex than that because the beat structure and the phrase structure is based on the larger bars. The reason you’re struggling to ‘think the rhythm’ is that the words fit the music in a very idiosyncratic way. Once you start to think of it in four slow beats, it will become clearer.
